docs.abstract: Harvard Nurses' Health Study, 25-year project, has found that even moderate exercise can help prevent heart disease in women (S)
docs.snippet: DR. JOANN E. MANSON exercises 20 or 30 minutes every morning on a treadmill or a rowing machine and takes a 10-minute walk every afternoon. She lifts weights for 15 minutes three times a week. Like her fellow investigators on the Harvard Nurses'...
docs.lead_paragraph: DR. JOANN E. MANSON exercises 20 or 30 minutes every morning on a treadmill or a rowing machine and takes a 10-minute walk every afternoon. She lifts weights for 15 minutes three times a week. Like her fellow investigators on the Harvard Nurses' Health Study -- a 25-year project that has produced a trove of medical findings -- she has become a believer in the preventive power of exercise. But for Dr. Manson, a 48-year-old professor at Harvard Medical School, the great delight in the study's findings about heart disease was the realization that ''no pain, no gain'' is a myth -- that even moderate exercise makes a big difference. The Nurses' Health Study began in 1976, when more than 120,000 nurses filled out questionnaires about their habits and their health. The survey has continued with questionnaires every other year, generating a vast array of information about heart disease, cancer and the effects of lifestyle choices like exercise, diet, alcohol and smoking.

headline.main: Even Light Exercise Can Help the Heart

docs.abstract: Health issues for every stage of woman's life have become big business for new magazines in last few years; mainstream magazines are taking notice, too, and jumping on health-reporting bandwagon; photo (M)
docs.snippet: IN the last few years, women's magazines that focus primarily on health issues have multiplied faster than multiple-birth baby strollers on the Upper East Side.     Where once there were two or three, now there is a health magazine for every stage of...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the last few years, women's magazines that focus primarily on health issues have multiplied faster than multiple-birth baby strollers on the Upper East Side. Where once there were two or three, now there is a health magazine for every stage of a woman's life, offering coverage of everything from the mommy track to menopause, from kundalini yoga to Kegel exercises, food allergies to folic acid.

headline.main: Looking for Health News? A Bikini Belly? There's More to Read

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody offers 10 tips to women on diet, exercise and lifestyle to keep heart healthy (S)
docs.snippet: You only have one heart. Here are 10 tips for keeping it healthy:    EXERCISE -- Get at least 30 minutes a day of moderately vigorous exercise, like brisk walking, cycling (indoors or out), dancing, jogging or lap swimming. Aerobic exercise makes...
docs.lead_paragraph: You only have one heart. Here are 10 tips for keeping it healthy: EXERCISE -- Get at least 30 minutes a day of moderately vigorous exercise, like brisk walking, cycling (indoors or out), dancing, jogging or lap swimming. Aerobic exercise makes your heart a more efficient pump and raises H.D.L. cholesterol, the ''good'' cholesterol that cleanses arteries.

headline.main: Tips to Keep the Pump Primed (It Isn't That Hard)

docs.abstract: Recent studies indicate that long-term drinking takes even greater toll on women than it does on men; women appear to suffer from many alcohol-related problems and illnesses at earlier stage than men; their risk of sustaining some kinds of liver, cardiac or neurological damage is greater, and their depression rates are higher; women with history of alcoholism, even far in past, report more trouble with daily functioning than men with similar histories; four million American women already suffer from what mental health professionals now call alcohol use disorders (M)
docs.snippet: ''Hello, you chaps.''    ''Hello, Brett,'' I said. ''Why aren't you tight?''
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Hello, you chaps.'' ''Hello, Brett,'' I said. ''Why aren't you tight?''

headline.main: Paying a Price for Drinking Men Under the Table

docs.abstract: Cosmetic medical techniques now offer full range of minimally invasive options that can tame anything from facial lines to bulging varicose veins; most techniques can be performed in doctor's office in about hour or less; last year, more than 1.3 million people had some kind of plastic surgery procedure; various procedures described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: LAST summer, Farley Clark began noticing the signs. ''I was starting to get a few little lines around my mouth and eyes and some frown lines on my forehead,'' she said. ''But I didn't think I needed a face-lift yet. I wanted something to perk me...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAST summer, Farley Clark began noticing the signs. ''I was starting to get a few little lines around my mouth and eyes and some frown lines on my forehead,'' she said. ''But I didn't think I needed a face-lift yet. I wanted something to perk me up.'' Looking youthful is important to Ms. Clark, a commercial real estate broker in Manhattan who gives her age as 50-ish. But any procedure with a long healing time was out of the question. ''In my business it's important to stay competitive,'' she said. ''I wanted to look good right away.''

headline.main: Banish Wrinkles in an Hour! (For a While, Anyway)

docs.abstract: Cardiologists say many women show little concern about heart disease and its consequences for them; say they are blase about disease that kills many and, contrary to popular belief, tends to work slowly and painfully, turning millions of women's final years into prolonged bout with chest pain, weakness, immobility and shortness of breath; say this endemic lack of awareness is particularly troubling because heart disease, unlike many other diseasess, is becoming more preventable; drawings; map; chart (M)
docs.snippet: STRESS, of course, is not good for you. But when it comes to heart disease and its consequences, cardiologists say they wish women would feel a little more of it.    Never in their memory, doctors say, have so many people been so blasé about a...
docs.lead_paragraph: STRESS, of course, is not good for you. But when it comes to heart disease and its consequences, cardiologists say they wish women would feel a little more of it. Never in their memory, doctors say, have so many people been so blasé about a disease that kills so many -- and, contrary to popular belief, tends to work slowly and painfully, turning millions of women's final years into a prolonged bout with chest pain, weakness, immobility and shortness of breath.

docs.abstract: About 90 percent of companies with at least 50 employees have program to promote healthy living that is aimed at decreasing health care costs and increasing employee productivity; programs vary from exercise classes to discounts on health insurance premiums; nearly all can have striking effect on production and women have record of participating more than men; photo; graph (M)
docs.snippet: AFTER Sharon Maynard's husband of 20 years decided he did not want to be married anymore, she felt her life slipping out of control -- and felt herself slipping into depression. As a single mother of a teenage son, she did not know what to think and...
docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER Sharon Maynard's husband of 20 years decided he did not want to be married anymore, she felt her life slipping out of control -- and felt herself slipping into depression. As a single mother of a teenage son, she did not know what to think and what to do and, least of all, where to turn for help. A year after her ordeal, Ms. Maynard, a 42-year-old purchasing agent, says she found solace from a source that may sound unlikely but is increasingly available to American workers: her employer.

headline.main: A Place Where They Don't Dread Coming to Work

docs.abstract: Heart disease is leading killer of American women by wide margin, but recent survey of women aged 25 and over finds far more concern about cancer; being convinced of risk of heart disease is only half the story; also at issue is lack of straightforward answers to questions about how to try to reduce risk of disease; there are uncertainties about risks and benefits of various kinds of exercise and about diet choices; drawings; chart (L)
docs.snippet: WOMEN are usually model patients, taking responsibility not just for their own health but also for the health of their husbands and children. We're much better than men about getting regular checkups, taking medications the way we're told to, reading...
docs.lead_paragraph: WOMEN are usually model patients, taking responsibility not just for their own health but also for the health of their husbands and children. We're much better than men about getting regular checkups, taking medications the way we're told to, reading up on illnesses that strike us or our loved ones, talking to other women with the same health concerns. Why, then, do we seem to have a blind spot when it comes to prevention? And why is it so hard for us to do the things we know we should do to reduce our risk of chronic illnesses -- especially the most dangerous of all, heart disease?

headline.main: Taking Care of Everybody but Herself

keywords.value: ST VINCENT'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
keywords.name: organizations

docs.abstract: Dorothy Cummings has spent 15 years as a nurse at St Vincents Hospital in New York City; along with hospital nurses around country, she struggles in era of staff shortages and managed care, rising patient loads and stagnant pay; her day-to-day pressures reveal much about spunk and difficulty involved in the job; photos (M)
docs.snippet: DOROTHY CUMMINGS once described the whir of working in an emergency room in musical terms, as though it could be conducted and, in some way, appreciated. When she begins her shift as a triage nurse at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center, it is 8...
docs.lead_paragraph: DOROTHY CUMMINGS once described the whir of working in an emergency room in musical terms, as though it could be conducted and, in some way, appreciated. When she begins her shift as a triage nurse at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center, it is 8 a.m. and usually quiet. The crises build as the day grows. Sometimes, she can almost taste the adrenaline as she registers patients arriving by ambulance or cares for them in one of six trauma wards. Even sitting within the tiny, isolated triage room -- what nurses here call the cage -- she can still feel the day bulge while cataloging the ailments of others: rib meat stuck in throat; hook caught in hand; vision left spotty after a topple from a trampoline.

headline.main: Healing and Burnout, 12 Hours at a Stretch

docs.abstract: Program called Look Good...Feel Better, addresses concerns of women living with effects of cancer and chemotherapy; in workshops led by cosmetologists, patients discuss ways of coping with drastic changes that come with loss of hair, eyebrows and eyelashes; program is sponsored by American Cancer Society with National Cosmetology Assn and Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Assn; photo (M)
docs.snippet: MY recent obsession with fashion began in a hospital, a few hours after my double mastectomy. In the wee hours of the morning, I crawled into the bathroom to exchange my hospital gown for a nightgown brought from home.  Shortly afterward, the night...
docs.lead_paragraph: MY recent obsession with fashion began in a hospital, a few hours after my double mastectomy. In the wee hours of the morning, I crawled into the bathroom to exchange my hospital gown for a nightgown brought from home. Shortly afterward, the night nurse came to change my bandages. ''How nice you look!'' she exclaimed. ''Eileen West,'' I replied smugly. ''Er, I assume you mean the nightgown, not the bandages.'' We made brief, meaningful eye contact. ''No,'' she said as she peeled back the adhesive tape. ''This is more Vera Wang.'' She was right: the smooth white bars dipping to a V over my sternum appeared bridal in nature. Surgeons think of these things.

headline.main: When Fashion and Makeup Do Wonders for the Spirit
